reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhancing access to quality health care services for vulnerable communities in five provinces

description.narrative:
The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) is the world's largest humanitarian organization, with 192 member National Societies. As part of the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement, our work is guided by seven fundamental principles: humanity, impartiality, neutrality, independence, voluntary service, unity and universality.
IFRC Country Office, which enjoys a status agreement in Afghanistan, supports Afghan Red Crescent Society (ARCS) in strengthening its capacities and implementing programs and operations across the country. ARCS is “working with people that no one else can reach” as per its Strategic Plan 2016-2020 and within a new legal framework: The Law for the regulation of the ARCS Affairs.
Health is a set of core programs and services of ARCS aimed to contribute in strengthening the primary health care in the country. Community Based Health Care is a core health component of ARCS which aims in improving access to basic health services, health education, WASH, first aid and emergency health response to vulnerable communities. The objective is to reduce health risks and improve community resilience. Currently ARCS contribute in health system of Afghanistan by provision of health services through 45 BHCs, 1 CHC, 70 MHTs, 22 health subcenters and one DH. ARCS also support treatment of children with congenital heart diseases in country and outside in India and China.
This project will implement in 5 provinces and provide integrated primary health care services to the targeted communities (IDPs, returnees and host communities).
1- IDPs and host community in Ab Kamari district of Badghis province. 2- Flood affected IDPs and host community in Nahre Seraj district of Helmand province. 3- Flood affected IDPs and host community in Khakriz district of Kandahar province. 4- IDPs settlement (Shahrake Sabz and Regrition) in Herat province. 5- IDPs and host community in Shahre Darzab, Azimabad and Belalabad villages of Sheberghan city, Jawzjan province.
It is since a year that ARCS is supporting mentioned targeted communities and due to the ground realities, there is need to extend the provision of primary health care services for another year. Targeted communities appreciated ARCS health care services and by continuation of support the expected gap will be covered. Through provision of health care services by 5 MHTs this project will reach totally 107,892 (male 40,133 female 67,759) beneficiaries, male and female, adult and children. As part of primary health care services, OPD, vaccination/immunization of children lt 5yrs and CBA women, RH including antenatal care, postnatal care, family planning, health education, risk communication, COVID-19 case detection and referral are part of this program.

title.narrative: Provision of life-saving trauma care, emergency PHC and COVID risk communication to the conflict-affected and vulnerable people in Paktika province.

description.narrative:
International Medical Corps (IMC) is a US-registered independent affiliate organization of International Medical Corps UK (IMC UK), with which IMC UK shares the same name and charitable objectives and mission. IMC UK and IMC work together to deliver assistance programs in an accountable and effective manner in pursuit of their commonly-held charitable objectives. IMC UK will engage IMC to implement its programs in the field, with IMC UK oversight, according to the terms and conditions of the agreement that results from this proposal and the terms of the parties’ administrative service agreement. Together with IMC Croatia, IMC provides administrative and operational support to IMC UK and to the programs on the ground, including but not limited to financial management, banking and cash management, procurement management/international procurements and logistics.
In consideration of the AHF 5th Reserve Allocation 2020, International Medical Corps (IMC) proposes to provide life-saving health services to the conflict-affected and hard-to-reach communities in Paktika province. As per IMC's coordination with key stakeholders in the area and secondary information, currently, there are critical gaps in healthcare services, especially trauma care and PHC services, forcing the majority of these communities to travel long distances to seek these services, resulting in disabilities, morbidity and mortality. On the other hand, COVID-19 has further deteriorated the situation for these vulnerable, crisis-affected and hard-to-reach communities, who have little or no awareness about COVID-19.
IMC has a strong presence and experience in the Paktika province as well as the expertise in the implementation of emergency health programs in similar contexts, IMC can leverage this capability and expertise to ensure the successful implementation of the proposed project. The interventions will take specific care to implement the program per the BPHS/EPHS guidelines and SPHERE standard, providing safe access for vulnerable groups, such as women and girls, to the services.
Through this project, IMC will contribute to the Health Cluster/sectors objectives through the following activities:
1. Establishment of 2 FATPs in 2 hard-to-reach districts (Giyan and Dila) of Paktika province to stabilize injured and refer to the nearest hospital for advanced care based on need 2. To provide a timely and standard referral, IMC will provide 2 Ambulances (one at each FATP) equipped and supplied with all necessary items to provide first -aid and basic life support. 3. Training of newly recruited nurses on BLS to provide quality trauma care services 4. Provision of medical supplies, medical equipment and medicines to the newly established FATPs and SHCs based on MOPH / WHO standard essential list 5. Establishment of two Health Sub-Centers (HSCs) in Gomal district to provide emergency primary health care including antenatal care services 6. Establish and operate Tele-health center at the Sharan Provincial hospital (PH) to provide awareness and RCCE on COVID-19 7. Training and mobilization of Community Health Workers (CHWs) to conduct awareness and community-based surveillance for COVID-19
IMC will implement the project in close coordination with Health Cluster, Paktika PHD, MoPH, BPHS/EPHS implementing organization and the communities at the national and local levels.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of essential and quality primary health care services, including sexual and reproductive health care for vulnerable conflict-affected population in Zabul Province.

description.narrative: The proposed action will address the health humanitarian needs of the conflict-affected population in Zabul Province, through the provision of primary health care services in Qalat and Shajoy districts. This action aims at improving access to basic primary health care (PHC), including sexual reproductive health (SRH) and COVID-19 specific support. In Qalat district, INTERSOS will focus particularly on supporting the Sexual and Reproductive Health services provided at Qalat temporary Provincial Hospital, while also improving the quality of outpatient department (OPD) consultations through the provision of additional space, medical equipment, drugs and human resources. 25.615 vulnerable individuals will benefit from this intervention. The project will: 1) support the provision of OPD consultations within Qalat temporary Provincial Hospital, through specialized medical personnel (medical doctors, nurses and midwives) expansion of space for consultations provision of proper medical equipment and drugs. 2) provision of primary health care services in hard to reach areas of Shajoy district through the deployment of a health team. 3) provision of personal protective equipment for medical personnel deployed in Qalat and Shajoy districts in order to prevent the further spread of COVID-19. INTERSOS will implement this project in synergy with ongoing actions within the same area. Particularly, a referral system will be put in place to the Family Protection Center (FPC) embedded in the Qalat Provincial Hospital. Through its comprehensive intervention, INTERSOS will address rising COVID-19 pandemic needs with prevention, preparedness and response integrated activities of Infection and Prevention Control (IPC), focused hygiene promotion and capacity building for front-line health workers.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of access to safe WASH services for displacement-affected communities in Kunduz Province

description.narrative:
The proposed project will target conflict-affected communities in Chardara, Qala-i-Zal and Dasti-Archi Districts of Kunduz Province through provision of adequate and sustainable Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) services at household and community-level. The project aims to improve access to safe water and sanitation facilities as well as hygiene items to the vulnerable households in underserved communities. The response covers a critical gap in hard-to-reach areas by providing or expanding existing WASH facilities in conflict affected communities. In addition, communities hosting IDPs or Afghan returnees whose WASH facilities are overstretched will be supported though WASH services. The project will be directly implemented by the Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), continuing recent interventions in these areas (Covid-19 response). The project is aligned with the AHF Allocation Response Strategy 5th RA and has been coordinated through relevant fora, notably the Afghanistan WASH Cluster.
Targeting 1,650 vulnerable households (11,550 individuals – 5,659 males 5,891 female) in Kunduz Province, NRC proposes to construct 3 new solar water supply system and rehabilitate/upgrade 33 existing water sources (boreholes and dug wells) through contractual services. In addition, 180 vulnerable families will be supported though conditional cash assistance for household latrine construction. Non-food items (NFI) hygiene kits and handwashing drums will be provided though in-kind distribution to the targeted households. All of the WASH project hard interventions will be complemented with soft component of hygiene promotion. The hygiene promotion session will be specifically focusing on prevention of COVID-19.
NRC will ensure that the cash-based programming under this component will follow both NRC’s Standard Operating Procedures (SoPs) and the Cash and Voucher Working Group’s (CVWG) recommendations on cash delivery mechanisms.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Inclusive COVID-19 Emergency WASH Response in Hard-to-Reach Areas of Badakhshan and Kunduz

description.narrative:
In Afghanistan, the pandemic comes at a time when the country is grappling with deadly conflict, severe food insecurity, and a dire economy that has plunged over 80% of the population below the poverty line (C-19 MSHCP). Existing WASH services including water and sanitation facilities were already unable to adequately support escalating WASH needs from conflict and natural disasters, without the added burden of COVID-19. According to IOM, the number of confirmed cases suggests that Afghanistan could have one of the highest infection rates in the world, with the Ministry of Public Health projecting over 25.6 million Afghans will be infected with the virus if serious action is not undertaken. With over 60% of COVID-19 tests allocated to just three of the country’s 34 provinces, humanitarian agencies continue to voice a lack of attention and support to other increasingly vulnerable areas. Accordingly, Kunduz and Badakhshan Provinces―the proposed area of intervention―have largely been neglected in terms of both testing and response, with 1,040 confirmed cases considered a severe underrepresentation of the current context (MoPH, 9/15/20). The lack of confirmed cases combined with rumors and limited access to reliable information have created a false sense of security, prompting communities to disregard vital prevention measures required to mitigate or reduce the likelihood of an outbreak.
Through a whole of community approach, Concern Worldwide is proposing inclusive and accessible COVID-19 emergency response in underserved, hard-to-reach areas of Yaftal and Arghanch Khwa districts of Badakhshan and Khanabad and Aliabad districts of Kunduz, entailing: 1) the installation of age, gender, and disability-inclusive handwashing stations at remote health care facilities and public gathering areas 2) the rehabilitation of damaged village hand pump wells that are safe and accessible to different vulnerability groups and 3) the targeted construction of safe and appropriate latrines for disabled and female-headed households. Specifically, Concern will install 960 communal handwashing stations at pre-identified vulnerable sites of target communities, taking into consideration age, gender, and disability access to ensure equal assistance. This includes sex-segregated facilities (where applicable), soak pits for water drainage, and an appropriate height for comfortable access and use by children, elderly, and people with a disability. Handwashing stations will be provided alongside a three-month supply of liquid soap, and will require the signing of an MoU that details sustained community-led maintenance and management, including proper transportation and storage of water. Additionally, through a community-based participatory approach, Concern will identify and rehabilitate 80 damaged hand pump wells that are accessible and safe for the whole community in order to address the prevalent lack of access to clean water. Existing CBOs, community leaders, and representatives of MRRD will be involved in the site selection process to ensure local buy-in and sustainability of the repaired infrastructure. Guided by inclusive Beneficiary Selection Committees (BSCs), Concern will identify 415 disabled and female-headed households that lack able-bodied members for the construction of sanitary latrines. Concern will abide by UNHCR’s protection checklist for sanitation facilities, including a safe location, proper lighting, minimum space standards, and locks on the inside for privacy and safety. Throughout project implementation, Concern will mainstream COVID-19 risk communication and awareness campaigns, including gender-sensitive hygiene promotion, rumor management, contextual mitigation measures, and available channels for health support. The timely provision of the WASH minimum package will establish the conditions that allow 63,720 people to live with good health, dignity, and comfort―which is particularly crucial in the context of a pandemic.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Procurement and Prepositioning of Core Supplies for WASH Response

description.narrative:
The COVID 19 Pandemic has significantly affected Afghanistan due to its weak health system and limited capacity to prevent the spread of the virus. High internal displacement and a weak water and sanitation infrastructure worsen the situation. A new wave of the virus feared to come during the winter of 2020 could add significantly to the agony of an Afghan population already grappling with the economic impact of the virus. According to the Afghanistan Humanitarian Response Plan (June 2020 update) as many as 35 million Afghans are in need of a social safety net, 14 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, while 7.2 million of those are in need of water, sanitation and hygiene assistance specifically.
DACAAR directly contributes to this plan and to the containment of the COVID-19 outbreak as well as to improving the overall WASH condition of at risk populations by procuring, prepositioning and making available handwashing soap as a core WASH pipeline supply in support of WASH Cluster partner response projects.
Handwashing with soap is considered as one of the most effective containment strategies for COVID 19 available to at risk populations. Procuring and supplying soap as a standalone hygiene item will be swift and will add to the agility of response by WASH partners. Given that this is a stockpiling project and the distribution of the supplies will be undertaken by other WASH partners, the target beneficiaries will not be assisted by DACAAR but by partners. DACAAR will report on the beneficiaries based on reports from WASH partners who accessed the stockpiles. Distribution by WASH partners to at risk families will be based on the Sphere Standard of a minimum of 250grams of soap per person per month. DACAAR will procure and preposition 651,000 bars of 130gram high quality anti-septic soap sufficient for 3 months use for 15,500 at risk families (108,500 individuals).
The soap supplies will be stocked in the following strategic geographical hubs: Kabul, Kandahar city Herat city Mazar-e-Sharif city Kunduz city Maimana city (Faryab) and in Talugan city (Takhar), with the potential of being moved to locations where need is greatest. These locations are central enough to be accessed by partners implementing WASH projects in the provinces prioritized in the AHF 5th reserve allocation strategy namely Badghis, Herat, Faryab, Zabul, Badakhshan, Nimroz, Kunduz and Jawzjan as well as from other provinces of the country. DACAAR will maintain sufficient flexibility to transfer supplies among the warehouses. Partners can readily access available stock of soap for use in their response projects based on approval from the WASH Cluster.
Procurement of the soap will be performed as part of a comprehensive Invitation to Bed (ITB) process following DACAAR procurement procedures (attached) which is line with AHF procurement regulations. The ITB process will include a market assessment enabling DACAAR to identify and contract the cheapest bidder who can deliver the highest quality soap. Procured soap will be checked stringently to ensure highest anti-septic quality (given recent lessons learned from the sector on fake Dettol soap in the market). The following will be performed during the ITB to ensure quality of soap procured - Physical Description : - Based on experience and technical knowhow , the assigned technical colleagues know the physical attribute of the quality soap required and check the delivered soap accordingly.
- Industrial Standards Certificate/ Proving Documents: - The bidders are usually asked for the required documents. A Sample is attached.
- Legal Import: - DACAAR buys legally imported Antiseptic Dettol Soap having proper custom clearance documents.
In addition to the above, DACAAR will reserve the right to perform laboratory examiniation of the soap with the help of Afghanistan National Standards Authority (ANSA).

title.narrative: Provision of protection services to children and women during winter season

description.narrative:
Children and women are one of the most vulnerable categories in the upcoming winter season who are detrimentally impacted by the livelihood crisis worsened by the COVID-19 pandemic which compounds the vulnerabilities arising from protracted conflict in Afghanistan. Children in Crisis is requesting $250K to mount a rapid response to mitigate and respond to the protection risks related to the current crisis and to increase access to essential information, supplies and services for 16000 conflict and crisis-affected individuals across Badakhshan, Bamiyan, Kabul and Paktika provinces. Protection programmes will be implemented in Faizabad, Kishma Argo districts in Badakhshan, Bamyan, Shibar, Panjab, Yakawlang districts in Bamyan, Kabul, Paghman, Shakar Darah, Guldara, Istalif districts in Kabul and Sharan, Yousufkhail, Gomal and Barmal districts in Paktika. These provinces have been classified as Priority 1 provinces and have the highest need for winterization assistance as per the Inter cluster Winterization Strategy 2020-21 Kabul among them has the highest number of people in need for winterization assistance. The project promotes the physical and psychosocial protection of vulnerable conflict and crisis-affected children and women during the upcoming winter season through (i) Case management services (which includes identification, intervention plan and referral services for children with vulnerabilities due to winter season and COVID-19 (ii) Establishment and training of community based protection committees to identify, respond to protection risks and incidents and refer and follow up for specific services and (iii) Provision of essential winterization kits. The strategic selection of these activities is intended to respond to protection risks of children in the immediate term compounded by the current crises, whilst building sustainable institutions to increase communities’ resilience to the long term, embedded protection risks for at risk children and the wider group of children. The project uses a scaffolded intervention that intensifies support and services across categories of increasing vulnerabilities: 2500 vulnerable households with more than four children, identified through vulnerability and needs assessment will receive essential life-saving winterization kits to support the children of households by providing warm clothes and blankets, that supports them to continue attending school, and interact with other children in public space during the winter season. 56 vulnerable communities shall benefit from the functional community based protection committees which shall be trained to mitigate and respond to protection risks of individuals and groups in the community 2900 vulnerable children (including children at significant risk: UASC, CAAFAG, street children, GBV survivors) shall benefit from the direct referrals and supplementary services provided by Children in Crisis. Specifically, 250 UASC children at significant risk due to separation from caregivers will receive counselling and case management services and 250 children at severe risk of exposure to exploitation and violence will receive specialized services including interim care, case management and family tracing and reunification.
Children in Crisis [CiC] is a protection sector specialist, recognized as one of the “Top Ten NGO” actors by the Child Protection Action Network [CPAN] in 2019. Our extensive experience and expertise in protection programming – with proven approaches to working with incarcerated children – positions us to implement an intensive intervention over a six-month project period. At present, CIC also operates an Education in Emergencies intervention targeting 3500 conflict-affected children in Uruzgan under the Afghanistan Humanitarian Fund approx. 20% of this intervention includes integrated protection activities that underscore our sustained commitment and capabilities in protection.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Winter Relief Assistance to 700 Most Vulnerable IDP, Returnee and Host Community Households in Sarobi district of Kabul Province and Center of Ghazni Province.

description.narrative: The proposed project aims to deliver cash and in-kind (multi-cluster) winterization assistance to most vulnerable IDP households affected by recent conflicts and natural disasters (floods) in Sarobi district of Kabul province and in Center of Ghazni province. While it will also deliver 15% of the cash and in-kind food assistance to most vulnerable Returnees and 10% to most vulnerable Host Community Households ensuring a community based approach to properly manage Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) and Accountability to Affected Population (AAP) within the overall implementation process. UNCONDITIONAL CASH ASSISTANCE: The “Cash for Heating Stove and Fuel Assistance” in the form of unconditional/unrestricted cash assistance and modality of “In-cash payment by FSP” will cover 700 households both in Kabul (300 HHs) and Ghazni (400 HHs) provinces. 200 USD per household in Kabul and 260 USD per household in Ghazni will be provided to target households as “one time assistance” and as per cluster approved packages for Kabul- 3 months and Ghazni- 4 months. For safe, accessible, transparent and accountable transfer of cash to target beneficiaries, we will procure financial services through a register/licensed Financial Service Provider (FSP) in compliance with our finance and procurement policies and guidelines. The request for quotations/services will be widely announced through ACBAR and social media platform, collected quotations will be analyzed against quality and cost effectiveness, a single FSP or two FSPs as deemed necessary will be selected, MoU(s) will be signed with them and will be introduced to project team to ensure they put necessary control measures in place within the overall process. IN-KIND FOOD ASSISTANCE: The 4 months food ration will be provided to 350 households both in Kabul (150 HHs) and Ghazni (200 HHs) provinces in 2 distribution cycles- to 50% of the households assisted with Cash to ensure the acute humanitarian needs are met for the persons of concern during upcoming harsh winter season. Our Procurement and Logistic Units will assist the project team in management of goods procurement and logistics align with our internal policies and AHF guidelines to address quality work, transparency and accountability within the process. The FSAC’s standard food monthly package includes 46 Kg fortified wheat flour, 4.5 Kg Vegetable Oil, 8.4 Kg pulses and 1 Kg iodized salt. As an active member of wide coordination network in Central and South East Regions (HRTs, OCTs, PDCs, PDMCs, PSN Network, Social Protection and clusters), as CBPM partner of UNHCR and emergency partner of WFP- we are closely working with UNHCR, OCHA, UNICEF, IOM, DRC, IRC, DACAAR, IR, IRW, SCI, SCA, CARE International and other national/international NGOs in the network as well as with government line departments and local administration to ensure our assistance reach to our beneficiaries in an safe, accessible, transparent and participatory manner and we also avoid any duplication in our response(s). The distribution points will be selected in coordination with government line departments, local administration and target communities ensuring that no potential barriers exist to restrict the beneficiaries from accessing the assistance in a safe and participatory manner. We will use cluster’s recommended tools for market assessments, multi-sectorial need assessments/beneficiary selection and Post Distribution Monitoring (PDMs) for both of the components (unconditional cash amp in-kind food) ensuring that the most vulnerable get both of the packages and others only receive unconditional cash assistance as planned. The PDMs should reveal that how the unconditional cash amp in-kind food assistance assisted the target population of concern to overcome the challenges during the harsh winter in respect to the project indicators. In coordination with DoPHs to coordinate and respect all COVID-19 protection measures within the overall process

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Comprehensive Winterisation Response in Underserved Communities of Kunduz and Takhar

description.narrative:
Due to the economic impact of COVID-19, an estimated 1.3 million Afghans will not have access to heating and fuel this winter, leaving them extremely vulnerable to below freezing temperatures (Joint Winterisation Strategy Afghanistan, 2020). In high altitude areas with cold climates and harsh weather conditions, lives are at risk within one day of exposure to the elements. Families may be pushed to employ negative coping mechanisms, which can often have serious protection implications for women and children.
In response, Concern Worldwide is proposing urgent and time-sensitive winterisation assistance to address the severe NFI needs of acutely vulnerable host, IDPs and returnee populations of Kunduz and Takhar provinces. The proposed target districts―Namakab and Chal of Takhar and Aqtash of Kunduz―were identified based on the agency’s demonstrated operational capacity and access, coordination with other humanitarian actors in the area, severity of winterisation needs, and lack of previous assistance. Specifically, Concern is prepared to respond to the critical NFI needs of 959 acutely vulnerable families with a comprehensive winterisation package of i) 3-month heating/fuel cash assistance ($200 per family) ii) in-kind standard blanket packages ($40 value per family) and iii) in-kind winter clothing kits ($65 value per family). The use of cash for heating and fuel support, backed by recent market assessments, PDMs, and REACH evaluations, provides families with the flexibility to purchase the most appropriate appliances for their specific shelter type. This includes a gas cylinder or Bukhari stove and 180 Kg of firewood or LPG. The provision of in-kind blanket packages and winter clothing kits will keep the immediate space around bodies warm, and significantly help vulnerable families cope with the winter season. While these items are intended to be distributed jointly, households that do not meet the criteria for all three packages will only receive the relevant assistance. Given the time-sensitive nature of this response, with winter quickly approaching, Concern will distribute the mentioned support via a single instalment.
During assessments and distributions, Concern will mainstream COVID-19 risk communication and awareness campaigns―including COVID-19 kits and hygiene promotion within winter sectorial response―as well as gender-sensitive behavioral change messaging to positively influence expenditure choices and coping strategies. Since the distribution is conducted in an closed space during winter, Concern will ensure to limit the number of beneficiaries per distribution and will provide masks to beneficiaries as well as project staff. Sanitizers will be procured to utilize by the beneficiaries and staff during the distribution. Gender, age, and disability considerations will be integrated as much as possible to ensure the response is inclusive to all segments of a community, particularly People with Specific Needs (PSNs). Winterisation response will place special attention towards children, the elderly, chronically ill, or those with limited mobility to deliver lifesaving insulation support to the most at-risk groups.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Winterization support for vulnerable people in Kunduz and Nangarhar

description.narrative: In line with the 6th AHF Reserve Allocation Strategy paper, the revised HRP 2018-2021 SO1, and the 2020-2021 Joint Winterization Strategy strategic objectives, Cordaid proposes to provide winterization assistance during winter in priority 1 areas Kunduz and Nangarhar, following the ESNFI recommended standard modalities for winterization. In the project 3 modolities (Cash, Vouchers and in kind is proposed to increased the effectiveness of the project. Total 2248 (2023 from AHF and 225 from Cordaid funds) HH will be covered from the project. In Kunduz (Kunduz City, Iman Sahib and Khan Abad) Cordaid will target 1,448 (1225 recently displaced HH who are assessed by Cordaid in October under START Funds and 223 new host) out of 1448 HH 225 2ill covered by Cordaid funding . Each of the HH will receive cash for heating materials @ US$200 through cash in envelop through Boloro (FSP) in a one off payment, and 3 sheets of blankets in kind. In Nangarhar (Achin, Nazyan, Kot and Batikot) 800 (570 existing beneficiates of ongoing Shelter and 230 food security projects funded by AHF) will be assisted with cash for heating materials @ US$200 through and Modality Vouchers for warm cloths of US$ 65. In Kunduz the project will be directly implemented by Cordaid while in Nangarhar the project will be implemented by OHW with technical support from Cordaid. The project is designed based on recent need assessments in both areas. In Kunduz 98% of the respondents is recently displaced, mentioning conflict as the main reason for their displacement. Because of their displacement people are very vulnerable. 98% of the people also indicated that they had not received any assistance. There is a large percentage of people with specific needs (PSN): 28% of the HH have at least one member with a disability or chronic disease (REACH), and 40% are PLW. In 84% of the Cordaid assessed HH is an ill or chronically ill person, a person who is in need of medical care or, a PWD. According to REACH ESampNFI Winterization evaluation (2019-2020), people’s top 3 reported most critically needed NFIs during the last winter period are firewood/charcoal/gas for heating (72%), blankets amp quilts and winter clothes (49%). This is confirmed by Cordaid assessment, almost all respondents mentioned to be in need of winterization assistance. In Nangarhar, assessments revealed that half of the responding HH were displaced, with conflict as the main reason for their displacement, further increasing their vulnerabilities and exposure to COVID-19. Nearly 1/5 of the HH reported having at least 1 member with a disability or chronic illness (REACH ESampNFI Winterization evaluation 2019-2020). Because of high coping strategies (82% of the respondents are resorting to negative coping mechanisms) combined with the majority of the people (83%) having a poor food consumption score and 99% having no food stocks at all, people in the assessed districts are severely and acute food insecure. With winter arriving soon, the respondents raised the need for heating materials (69% of the respondents), warm clothes (87%) and blankets (49%). With reduced income, increase in cost of living and limited job opportunities (80% and 67% is unemployed in Kunduz and Nangarhar respectively) people lack the means to protect themselves against winter and are likely to resort to negative coping strategies to keep themselves warm this winter. The cash will be provided for heating materials because of market functionality. The blanket will be deliver to the beneficiary because of the bulk procurement and will cost us lower the then local markets . Cordaid is leveraging US$ 54,495 from its own funds to the project to reach more people. Cordaid is committed to the ‘Grand Bargain’: in addition to participation, the use of cash transfers and transparency (ReportHub/IATI) implementation is jointly with OHW.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Winterization Assistance for Vulnerable Households in Daykundi and Samangan

description.narrative:
According to the Joint Winterization Strategy (dated July 2020) and ESNFI cluster data, 504,000 people in Daykundi and 448,000 people in Samangan will be exposed to harsh winter weather in the coming winter season. The Covid-19 pandemic has led to widespread illness and mortality, a deep economic recession, and starkly reduced income opportunities in these provinces, which in turn has depleted productive assets and reduced communities’ capacity to cope with shocks. Afghanaid’s recent needs assessment (Annex A) found that the vast majority of households in both provinces are unable to cover their basic needs and require urgent assistance.
In line with ESNFI cluster priorities detailed in the Joint Winterization Strategy, Afghanaid proposes to provide crucial heating and blanket assistance to 2127 vulnerable households in Aybak and Hazrat-e Sultan districts of Samangan, and Sang-e Takht, Khedir and Ishterlay districts of Daykundi, which are all prioritized by the ESNFI cluster under this allocation. Based on communities’ preference for cash transfers and a recent market assessment (Annex B) confirming community access to well-functioning markets, Afghanaid proposes cash as the modality for heating assistance. In line with cluster preferences, cash assistance will be complemented with in-kind assistance 25% of the most vulnerable targeted households (187 in Samangan and 359 in Daykundi) will also receive in-kind blanket packages.
In Samangan, the intervention will provide 280 households in Aybak and 468 in Hazrat-e Sultan with a standard 3-month heating package of US$200 per household, and 187 of these households will also receive an in-kind blanket package consisting of three double-sized blankets in line with cluster standards. In Daykundi, Afghanaid will provide 500 households in Sang-e Takht, 500 in Khedir and 379 in Ishterlay with standard 4-month heating packages of US$260 per household, and 359 of these households will also receive an in-kind blanket package. In Sang-e Takht and Khedir, the proposed winterization response will be complemented with a FSAC-funded cash for food intervention, ensuring that vulnerable households’ multiple needs are met in these areas of great need.
Afghanaid will establish participant selection and distribution committees including representatives from local communities (e.g. CDC and DDA heads), government (e.g. ANDMA and DoRR) and Afghanaid. Participants will be selected according to ESNFI vulnerability criteria to ensure the most acutely in need are targeted, including IDPs, women-headed households and households with a large number of dependent children.
The project team will work with a reliable saraf in each province to distribute the heating cash from central distribution points in a single tranche to ensure that assistance reaches the participants as soon as possible. Participants with limited mobility will be brought to the distribution point or receive the assistance at home.
Afghanaid is well placed to implement this project, with several years of presence in Daykundi, current operations in the target district and excellent access and strong relationships with communities as well as district and provincial authorities. Afghanaid has extensive experience in humanitarian programming, with current and recent humanitarian assistance projects in multiple provinces including Daykundi, funded by AHF, WFP, FAO, and ECHO. The projects include emergency food, livelihoods, winterization, and shelter assistance, using both in-kind and cash modalities.
This intervention will provide 14,889 vulnerable men, women, boys and girls with crucial heating and blankets, reducing illness and mortality and increasing participants’ capacity to rebuild their livelihoods by avoiding the sale of productive assets, so that they are more resilient against future shocks.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of immediate winterization assistance to people in need in high priority location of Khost province.

description.narrative: CAHPO’s proposed intervention is an emergency delivery measure intended to ensure a timely and effective response to humanitarian needs arising from conflicts, natural disasters, and other emergencies in the south-eastern region of Afghanistan (Khost province with is the 2nd priority in the winterization strategy). The intervention will focus on meeting the urgent humanitarian needs of internally displaced people and families within the targeted provinces of Khost as well as those fleeing to this province to seek shelter from outstanding challenges in adjacent provinces. Through implementation of the proposed project, CAHPO intended to support 1,135 affected families in Khost province to save their lives through provision of winterization support such as heating fuel/gas, winter clothing and blankets. CAHPO targets a total of 7,945 beneficiaries (2,660 individuals in Gurbaz district, 2,730 in Tanay district and 2,555 individuals in Nadirshakot district) for all three types of activities such as Winter Clothing, Blankets and heating materials. The number of beneficiaries for each type of activity will be determined based on the initial assessment in these three districts. CAHPO will determined the type of heating materials (Gas stove, fuel/gas) based on the findings from the assessment in each location with USD 200 per family. Providing heating support in kind is more favorable for many vulnerable families such as disabled or female-headed families in the target areas. Moreover, in-kind heating can be valuable for filing a winterization gap at a crucial time (without spending time by families to buy and transfer heating items). CAHPO will contract at the nearest possible level to distribute/provide the heating materials to the selected families. CAHPO will conduct an assessment to identify the needs of selected beneficiary for the mentioned assistances with a proper categorization for heating stove with fuel/gas, clothes and blankets. CAHPO will ensure that the most vulnerable people in need are prioritized for the winterization using selected criteria, including female-headed household child-headed household disabled headed household elderly headed household very large family (8 members or more) very poor families families with chronically- ill members or having other pressing vulnerability. The winterization items will be procured under the supervision of committee and will be delivered to identified beneficiaries by the distribution committee. CAHPO will properly coordinate the implementation process with all actors in the area as it was coordinated in the planning stage. A post-distribution monitoring will be conducted with a sample of beneficiary households. Furthermore, CAHPO will ensure that any negative impact that the project could have on women, men and children will be timely identified and addressed by the project team. The proposed activities and locations were coordinated through relevant ESNFI and AHF partners during the concept note submission to avoid duplication of services. Coordination will be continued throughout the project cycle at various levels. CAHPO has a presence in Khost since 2013 and implemented projects in past and created active social networks among the community for humanitarian and development purposes which will contribute to the effective implementation of the project. Since the assistances under this project is delivered during the COVID-19 pandemic, all measures and WHO COVID-19 and Health sector guidance will be considered during the implementation. CAHPO is currently reviewing internal available resources if we could provide additional support to more vulnerable families. CAHPO will keep informed the clusters and AHF if our internal resources can provide additional assistances. However, using our internal resources, there will be contribution from CAHPO staff at national/provincial levels who have not been allocated under this project.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Food assistance to the vulnerable population in Kamdish district of Nuristan Province

description.narrative:
Information provided by REACH and the Afghanistan Food Security Outlook Update August 2020 (based on data from FEWS network) shows that as a result of overall insufficient income due to prolonged impacts of conflict on livelihood activities, the majority of poor rural households are expected to be unable to meet all essential food needs. The overall needs assessment shows a prediction of 40% of the population living in IPC 3 or IPC 4 food security situation during coming winter.
In line with the AHF and adapted HRP 2020, ZOA-SHPOUL will provide food assistance through the implementation of cash for food project in Kamdesh district of Nuristan. The intervention will be through restricted and unconditional cash distribution. Cash will be distributed in 2 installments of USD 90 to cover 50% of the minimum food basket for 4 months. This modality is chosen as it empowers beneficiaries to have more control over their own resources which will maintain their dignity as they have a choice.
1072 HHs with a total of 7500 beneficiaries in Kamdesh will receive four half food package distribution through cash for food package. The provision will be in two installments in order to be most cost effective and to avoid the distributions being hindered by heavy snowfall. A proven Hawala will facilitate the distribution at Barikot,a village belonging to the Narai district. It has been the usual distribution point in the past and has proven to work well, beneficiaries are able to travel to that point. The distribution will be done based on the signed lists and/or tokens issued to the selected beneficiaries by the Beneficiary Selection Committee (BSC) through the Hawala system. In Kamdesh the network coverage is less than 20% hence more than 80% of the beneficiaries will not be able to make use of the phone. Representatives of the Community Development Committee (CDC) consisting of 10 ‘senior’ community members (F/M) will be involved in contacting beneficiaries if needed and NIDs will be checked. The cash distribution covers 50% of the accepted monthly MEB for an average Afghan family, it is expected that families will be able to cover the remaining needs. Information will be shared regarding the required food items to be purchased.
Besides the cash distribution, community mobilizers conduct awareness training on COVID-19, and how to potentially mitigate Sexual Gender-Based Violence (SGBV), and Domestic Violence (DV) in the families, including a focus on child rights. Awareness raising will take place in all villages in separate male/female groups, female beneficiaries receive the hygiene kit. Information leaflets will be distributed to ensure ongoing access to information.
Covid-19 and Protection awareness-raising sessions also take place at the distribution site. Key people of each village participate in community dialogues in order to discuss protection issues and information will be shared about other services available within the area to enable women to potentially get in touch with support services. This will however continue to be a challenge due to the remoteness and small number of health facilities available.
Kamdesh has small shops in some of the villages, these shops cannot fulfill the demand for the required food items. The market assessment done by SHPOUL local staff was focused on the market of Narai, a district in Kunar Province which touches Kamdesh. The market in Narai is able to deal with the demand for food items, the population of Kamdesh usually purchases their food items there. The market is accessible on foot, donkey, and the occasional car. The communities are stable hence social cohesion is reasonably strong through which community members support each other, in particular the elderly, people with disabilities, and female-headed households. For Female/children/elderly/PWD headed households the distribution will take place at Kamdesh centre to ensure a safe and secure distribution accessible to all.

participating-org.narrative: Sound Humanitarian Participatory amp; Organizational Uplift (SHPOUL)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of emergency cash for food assistance in Samangan province

description.narrative:
Through this project, ACTED will provide immediate life-saving food security assistance to 13,104 vulnerable and food insecure beneficiaries (1,872 households) in Samangan province.
The humanitarian situation in Afghanistan continues to steadily decline in late 2020, characterized by high levels of ongoing violence and conflict, natural disasters, high rates of poverty, and the COVID-19 pandemic, which have contributed to worsen the grave protection crisis and cause significant displacement and high multi-sector needs across the country. Populations are characterized by low resilience and high vulnerabilities and often fall into a state of acute emergency and need urgent support to meet their immediate basic needs. The COVID-19 pandemic in particular has had a significant acute impact across Afghanistan, and exacerbated already high levels of multi-sector needs for vulnerable communities due to loss of livelihoods and income, and reduced access to essential services as a result of government imposed lockdowns, movement restrictions and market volatility, which has eroded coping mechanisms and increased negative coping strategies.
Within this context, food insecurity remains severe across Afghanistan, and has worsened due to COVID-19. Most notably, the socio-economic impact of COVID-19 is having a devastating impact on people’s livelihoods and income, and coupled with chronic underlying poverty, has already started to further challenge families’ capacity to purchase essential food supplies. The lockdown and restrictions of mobility has had a negative impact on both the supply chain for basic commodities as well as on household livelihood and income opportunities, subjecting vulnerable households to reduced income, higher prices of food commodities, and reduced access to food due to supply chain disruptions. Samangan province is specifically facing this worsening situation. The latest IPC analysis projects Samangan as escalating to IPC Phase 4 (Emergency) from November 2020 to March 2021, and it is projected to have 40% of its urban population either in Phase 3 (Crisis) or 4 (Emergency).
ACTED is uniquely positioned to provide immediate food security cash assistance support vulnerable households in Samangan province and will provide cash assistance to cover four months half food ration (45 USD per HH per month x 4 months) to the most vulnerable beneficiaries to help support them during the lean season. In total, ACTED will target 872 households in Khuram wa Sarbagh districts and 1,000 households in Ruy-e-Duab district with cash assistance. The cash assistance will be heavily linked with and complemented by multi-sector responses, especially winterization assistance, in order to ensure that beneficiaries’ high multi-sector needs (particularly in winterization, health and WASH through various other funding streams, including another AHF allocation) are met and addressed during the winter months, and that the unconditional cash for food assistance will contribute to meeting their food needs.
