title.narrative: Food Assistance for 2486 Vulnerable Households in Daykundi

description.narrative:
According to the November 2020 IPC Acute Food Insecurity Analysis, 284,077 people in Daykundi, 55% of the population, will be in IPC Phase 3 and 4 and will experience acute food insecurity through the winter season. The Covid-19 pandemic has led to widespread illness and mortality, a deep economic recession, and starkly reduced income opportunities in the province, which in turn has depleted productive assets and reduced communities’ capacity to cope with the long lean season, which lasts through May. Afghanaid’s recent needs assessment (Annex A) found that the vast majority of households in Daykundi province are unable to cover their basic needs and require urgent assistance, with virtually all households surveyed (98%) citing food assistance as one of their most important needs.
In line with FSAC priorities detailed in the Joint Winterization Strategy and the cluster’s specific priorities for this allocation, Afghanaid proposes to provide crucial food assistance to 2486 vulnerable households in Sang-e Takht and Khedir districts of Daykundi, both of which are prioritized by the cluster under this allocation. Based on communities’ preference for cash transfers and a recent market assessment (Annex B) confirming market access and the local availability and affordability of standard food items, Afghanaid proposes cash as the modality for the assistance.
As per cluster priorities for this allocation, the intervention will provide 1286 households in Sang-e Takht and 1200 households in Khedir district with 4 standard half rations for a total of US$180 per household. The proposed food assistance will complement a separate, ESNFI-funded response in Daykundi and Samangan through which Afghanaid will provide 500 of the same households in Sang-e Takht and 500 of the same households in Khedir with standard 4-month heating packages of US$260 per household, and 359 of these households will also receive an in-kind blanket package. This ensures that the most vulnerable households’ multiple needs are met in these areas of great need, and the complementarity of these responses helps reduce the incentive to sell-off winterization assistance to cover food consumption needs, in line with cluster priorities as detailed in the Joint Winterization Strategy.
Afghanaid will establish participant selection and distribution committees including representatives from local communities (e.g. CDC and DDA heads), government (e.g. ANDMA and DoRR) and Afghanaid. Participants will be selected according to FSAC vulnerability criteria to ensure the most acutely in need are targeted, including IDPs, women-headed households and households with a large number of dependent children.
To ensure a cost effective and rapid response, the project team will work with a reliable saraf in each district to distribute the cash for food from central distribution points in two tranches of US$90 each. Participants with limited mobility will be brought to the distribution point or receive the assistance at home.
Afghanaid is well placed to implement this project, with several years of presence in Daykundi, current operations in the target districts and excellent access and strong relationships with communities as well as district and provincial authorities. Afghanaid has extensive experience in humanitarian programming, with current and recent humanitarian assistance projects in multiple provinces including Daykundi, funded by AHF, WFP, FAO, and ECHO. The projects include emergency food, livelihoods, winterization, and shelter assistance, using both in-kind and cash modalities.
This intervention will provide 17,400 vulnerable men, women, boys and girls with crucial food assistance, reducing illness and mortality as a result of food shortages and increasing the participants’ capacity to rebuild their livelihoods by avoiding the sale of productive assets, so that they are more resilient against future shocks.

job-title.narrative: Deputy Director of Finance amp; Administration

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Lifesaving intervention for multiple shock affected population at risk of hunger and malnutrition through cash for food distribution in Ghor Province, Afghanistan

description.narrative:
The proposed action’s objective is to improve the food security status of multiple-shock-affected population and mitigate their risk to face malnutrition through cash for food assistance during the harsh winter and lean season in Dawlatyar and Lal Wa Sarjangal districts of Ghor Province.
Ghor Province is, according to all the assessments done in Afghanistan (HNO/HRP 2020, SFSA, IPC, FEWSNET) one of the most affected provinces in Afghanistan in terms of food insecurity. Mostly mountainous with limited arable land, Ghor has the highest deficit of wheat in the country. This province has the history of being classified in Emergency Phase (IPC Phase 4) during the past years. As of IPC September 2020 Analysis, Ghor province had 25% of its population in IPC 4 and 35% of its population in IPC 3.
COVID-19 also has had an impact on this already fragile province. Unusually high food prices linked to border closures and panic buying, caused by COVID-19, further exacerbated food access of households already living below the poverty line. Food commodity prices have increased to between 10% and 20% (IPC analysis April-November 2020 and WFP market monitoring 2019-2020). Moreover, it is expected that the food security situation in Ghor will further deteriorate with the arrival of the winter. As the harvest season is over, labor and job opportunities will decrease and the purchasing power of the local population will drastically drop. This along with the peak in food prices due to the heavy snowfall blocking the roads will severely limit the access to diversified food during the harsh months of winter.
To address the emergency food insecurity situation in Ghor Province, AAH will deliver cash for food of the equivalent of 4 half rations for 17,000 individuals. These 17,000 individuals will be provided with unrestricted and unconditional cash. However, strong sensitization will be done by AAH teams before and during the distributions about food diversity to encourage households to spend their cash on diversified and highly nutritious food. This will prevent the households to engage in negative coping strategies that may result in loss of essential livelihood assets and therefore, increase their food consumption and dietary diversity.
The expected impact of this cash-based intervention is that vulnerable households do not exhaust their harvest during the lean season and have uninterrupted access to diversified food during the upcoming harsh months of winter, avoiding a further deterioration of their food security status.
This will be a six-month project, from 1st of December 2020 until 31st of May 2021, just before the start of the harvest in Ghor Province.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency Food Assistance through cash distribution in Hazrat-e-Sultan district of Samangan province.

description.narrative: Afghanistan remains one of the most vulnerable countries in the world. A complex and protracted conflict, the effects of climate change, demographic shifts, limited employment opportunities, pervasive gender inequalities and slow progress towards inclusive and transparent institutions have slowed down the country's development efforts. The IPC acute food insecurity analysis issued for Afghanistan in November 2020 projects that 13.15 million people (42% of the population) will be affected by high levels of food insecurity (IPC levels 3 crisis and above) between November 2020 and March 2021. Furthermore, OCHA predicts that the number of individuals affected by food insecurity may rise to 17 million. Specifically, Samangan province is classified as IPC level 4 emergency, with roughly 215,000 individuals (50% of the local population) affected by hunger and malnourishment. Additionally, the 2019-2020 Afghanistan Winterization evaluation reveals that a lack of humanitarian support results in households adopting negative coping strategies and being placed in more vulnerable and desperate situations. COVID-19 came up to further destabilise the vulnerability of the population. In Hazrat-e-Sultan, the district targeted by this intervention, only 34% of interviewed women of reproductive age were eating five or more food groups and only 29% of the households had food consumption score at the acceptable level. 78% of the households had “poor” food expenditure share and 50% of the households had high rCSI. 15% of the households were headed by children and women where majority of women headed households were widows and 11% of the households were headed by disabled persons. Only 29% of the population has an acceptably food consumption score, and 85% of the population relies on reduced coping mechanisms. In order to address the increased food and nutrition security risks and avoid the most vulnerable households to further resort to negative coping strategies during the winter season, Welthungerhilfe will provide timely lifesaving food assistance to 1,071 households (7,500 individuals) of the most vulnerable families in Hazrat-e-Sultan district in Samangan. In addition to food assistance, beneficiaries will receive nutrition and hygiene awareness sessions. The selected modality for the food assistance is cash. This modality has been prioritised following the market analysis that indicates that markets are accessible, functional and food and non-food items are available. In addition, cash is the preferred disbursement modality for the local population, as they expressed to Welthungerhilfe. Each vulnerable household will receive a total amount of USD 45 per month, for a total of USD 180 covering four months of food assistance. The cash distributions will be organised in two times (each two months) through hawala dealers. Welthungerhilfe has a vast experience in disbursing cash through hawala in the area targeted by the project. The distribution of cash will be conditional to the beneficiaries participating of the nutrition and hygiene promotion sessions. Distributions are organised considering specific needs of the population and gender-age considerations. In addition, Welthungerhilfe has put in place strong protocols to prevent further spread of COVID-19. In order to ensure the accurate identification of the most vulnerable, while engaging communities for the identification of the most vulnerable, Welthungerhilfe will consult the CDC, and at the same time, conduct sound independent verification surveys based on the methodology proposed by WFP. In addition, the setup of the CRM will allow the timely identification of inclusion and exclusion errors. All targeting errors identified are discussed and addressed with the communities and CDC. The success of this project will be measured through a strong MEAL system that includes baseline, endline and PDM, and which will be complemented by market follow ups and a learning workshop.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Cash-Based Emergency Food Assistance to shock-affected families in Waygal and Wama Districts of Nuristan

description.narrative:
According to the recent IPC analysis result, 94,903 people (45% of the population in Nuristan will be in IPC Phase 3 amp 4 (emergency and crises) and will experience acute food insecurity through the winter season. As per the result of the 2020 Seasonal Food Security Assessment (SFSA) shows 52% of the population in borderline FCS and 32.9% in poor FCS. On top of this, 95% of the households reported experiencing a recent shock. The major shocks faced by respondents were loss of employment, reduced income followed by severe sickness or death of breadwinner (due to COVID-19) together with a huge increase in food prices.
In line with the priorities of the 6th RA 2020, AWRO will provide cash for food assistance to 1,786 HHs in Wama and Waygal districts with 4 half rations for a total of US$180 per household. This amount is based on the FSAC endorsed standard package (calculated based on 2,100 kcal/person/day food needs of an average size family and the market price of food items). Cash will be distributed in two installments.
1. Waygal district 914 multiple shock-affected Families (1376 Men, 1728 Women, 1556 Boys and 1740 Girls) Will receive US$ 180 for four months food assistance (Half package of FSAC Standard food basket of family (90 US$/month x 2 = US$ 180). 2. Wama district 871 multiple Shock-affected Families (1311 Men, 1628 Women, 1503 Boys and 1658 Girls) Will receive US$ 180 for four months food assistance (Half package of FSAC Standard food basket of family (90 US$/month x 2= US$ 180).
For this assignment, AWRO will use the local Tellers’ services/Money Service Providers (Hawala/MPS) system based on CVWG response criteria as there are Money Service Providers available to provide services for cash transmission, available in Nuristan province. There are two banks available in the province (1 governmental, 1 private), but the MSPs are more available and easy-to-access for the target beneficiaries as there are over 15 MSP shops available in there. Except the Fridays which are official holiday, the money service providers are available throughout the week. The availability of Money Services Providers MSPs (Local Hawala) is ensured and physically checked. In order to effectively avoid currency loss, it’s important to provide market based cash response in AFN currency as the target people are not accustomed to USD currency as all transactions are carried out in AFN currency throughout the province.
AWRO will establish participant selection and distribution committees including representatives from local communities (e.g. CDC and DDA heads), government (e.g. ANDMA and DoRR) and AWRO. Participants will be selected according to FSAC vulnerability criteria to ensure the most acutely in need are targeted, including IDPs, women-headed households and households with a large number of dependent children.
Taking account of the “Do No Harm” policy this assignment will not negatively affect the market, prices or the transactions, instead, it would be an added value and multiplier to inject cash into the market.
Besides the cash distribution, community mobilizers will conduct awareness training on COVID-19, and how to potentially mitigate Gender-Based Violence (GBV) in the families, including a focus on child rights. Awareness-raising will be conducted in all villages in separate male/female groups, information leaflets will be distributed to ensure ongoing access to information.
Covid-19 and Protection awareness-raising sessions also take place at the distribution site. Key people of each village participate in community dialogues in order to discuss protection issues and information will be shared about other services available within the area to enable women to potentially get in touch with support services. This will however continue to be a challenge due to the remoteness and a small number of health facilities available.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency Lifesaving Nutrition Services in the low coverage high caseload districts in Badghis Province

description.narrative:
The designed project aims at ensuring delivery of adequate nutrition/health services, including the malnutrition treatment compromised due to the movement restrictions and other stressors. The disruption of nutrition service provision due overburdened health facilities is expected to deteriorate the nutrition status of children, as well as pregnant and lactating women in the pre-defined high-risk districts (Qadis, Jawand and Abkamari in Badghis province). World Vision (WV) Intends to deliver the required nutrition services through the establishment of 3 Mobile Health and Nutrition teams as well as strengthening decentralized nutrition services in 10 Sub-Health Centers (SHC) in these districts. World Vision will also focus on CHWs, Family Health action Groups to learn key Maternal Infant and Young Child Feeding and nutrition (MIYCN) to increase community awareness on key respective practices. In addition, under this project World Vision promote mother MUAC approach to put mothers at the center of malnutrition screening. The mother MUAC strategies acknowledge that mothers are in the best position to detect the earliest signs of malnutrition and leverages the fact that mothers want to participate as fully as possible in promoting the health and nutrition of their children. The mothers will report on MUAC screening once a month. Further the proposed project will work to strengthen the capacity of Family Health Action Groups, female volunteers and CHWs in Infant and Young Child Feeding to promote key IYCF practices and counselling based on the WHO guideline under the COVID-19 circumstances. These groups will be trained to respond the question of key community members and women in childbearing ages in relation on promotion of breastfeeding and be able to respond any questions that may be asked by each member of the community. The project will focus on early action to avoid severe malnutrition so the project will cover the, borderline’ cases of acute malnutrition through prevention-oriented services such as counselling on optimal care practices to mothers of children who are borderline in terms of their Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC). This approach has potential to reduce the risk of rapid deterioration of the nutritional status of children with a MUAC result of 12.5-13.5 cm. This will be done at the MHNTs level by nutrition nurse and at the community level by community nutrition promoters. The adaptation mechanism will be taken into consideration during any capacity building efforts, IYCF promotion session based on the WHO/MOPH and WV Standard Operating Procedure for training, public gatherings, IEC distribution under the COVID-19 circumstances. The project will focus on the provision of lifesaving referral for those cases that require inpatient services and will ensure that a transportation and treatment facility are provided for them. WV attends the EPR meetings on a weekly basis and will update the key actors including DoPH, UNICEF and WHO on the project progress the project report will be shared on a weekly and monthly basis to the key nutrition cluster focal points and DEWS surveillance focal points. In the EPR meetings, various issues are discussed such as places where the new MHNTs should operate and take proper measures to avoid overlap of same interventions.
The project will focus on provision and maintenance of the heaters for each section of the MHNTs activities and in particular on the nutrition spaces and will make sure solid and proper winterization plan in place.
The project will use the community health promoter and nutrition nurses to record all the children with disabilities as well as disabled PLW in a separate registration book and ensure they receive proper medical assessment and receive curative and counseling health and nutrition service. Through GIK WV will distribute the wheel-chair to them and ensure MHNT and SHC are friendly enough for the children and PLWs with disability.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Lifesaving Integrated Nutrition Response to Prevent Maternal and Child Morbidity and Mortality in Priority Districts of Ghor Province

description.narrative:
The proposed action’s objective is to contribute to reducing child and women morbidity and mortality related to malnutrition by the establishment of Mobile Health Teams (MHTs), support to a Sub-Health Center (SHC) and the establishment of Infant and Young Child Feeding (IYCF) corners in Ghor Province.
Ghor province is already affected by cycles of heavy armed conflict and natural disaster like drought and heavy rain causing flash floods. The province has very high needs in terms of nutrition, as highlighted in the different IPC reports. Especially the IPC report released in November 2020 identified Ghor as one of the main provinces affected by acute malnutrition. The emergence of the COVID-19 outbreak is also disastrous considering the fragile health system in this province. Finally the winter is a critical period in the province due to its high latitude, low temperature, heavy snow and roads blocked, isolating the province from the rest of the country.
The proposed intervention consists of two axes:
- The provision of nutrition management services to children under 5 (CU5) and pregnant and lactating women (PLW) suffering from Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) and Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM). Management services are key to prevent the mortality of the most malnourished children suffering from SAM are in average nine times more likely to die than their healthy peers. MAM CU5 and PLW will be admitted into the Supplementary Feeding Programme (SFP), whereas SAM CU5 will be admitted in Outpatient Therapeutic Programme (OTP). AAH will offer the ambulatory SFP and OTP services through two modalities: two MHTs will be deployed to Chaghcharan and Dawlatyar districts, reaching an average of 10 villages each and AAH will hire a Nutrition nurse and a Screener in a BPHS implementer-run SHC in Chaghcharan where a gap in nutrition services has been identified.
- The provision of IYCF counselling and good care practices sensitization to tackle misconceptions about breastfeeding and enable the healthy development of the infants in their first years. AAH will sensitize on IYCF and good care practices through different modalities: at the MHT by AAH midwife and nurse, through Family Health Action Groups (FHAG) and AAH Community Promoters in the villages targeted by the MHTs (Chaghcharan and Dawlatyar districts), at the SHC by the Nutrition Nurse in Chaghcharan, and at four IYCF and Breastfeeding corners established in Basic Health Centers (BHCs) in Shahrak, Doleena, Pasaband and Lal districts.
AAH will establish FHAG in the communities targeted by the MHTs. Close coordination will be maintained with these FHAG, AAH Community Promoters and SHC Community Health Workers (CHW) to ensure smooth referrals of detected or suspected MAM and SAM cases to AAH nutrition programs in the targeted locations.
To increase the chances of recovery of admitted SAM and MAM CU5 and PLW, AAH-run MHTs will also offer basic health services particularly targeting these groups: Sexual and Reproductive Health (SRH) consisting of antenatal and postnatal care and family planning services, and Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI).
As people with disability (PWD) are also an important part of the community, AAH will ensure that the teams will reach those PWD in the communities and provide them with equal services (based on needs) in the mobile site, in SHC and IYCF Corners supported by AAH.
AAH is supporting actively the good coordination of humanitarian activities in Afghanistan, especially for the Nutrition Sector through the allocation of a senior staff, with long nutrition experience in different contexts with AAH, for the position of Co-Lead of the Nutrition Cluster. This position will be covered partially by this grant, and AAH is taking the responsibility to cover the remaining months with other sources of funding.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Treatment of Moderate Acute Malnutrition among children aged 6-59 months as well as pregnant and lactating women

description.narrative: Ongoing conflict induced insecurity, low coverage of basic services, extreme winter conditions coupled with the impact of natural disasters have exacerbated the existing vulnerabilities of communities and resulted to very high rates of acute malnutrition. The COVID-19 pandemic has further aggravated the nutrition situation with over 15% increase in admissions of malnourished children and women in treatment centres. According to the Nutrition Cluster 2020 humanitarian needs severity ranking of April 2020, two-thirds of the provinces in the Afghanistan are currently above the alarming threshold of acute malnutrition with a global acute malnutrition - GAM ≥10 per cent with aggravating factors. With the oncoming winter, it is expected that the nutrition status of the most vulnerable population groups (children and PLW) will be deteriorate as a result of decreased access to adequate diets and increased morbidity coupled with reduced access to health services. Children and PLW living in provinces with the highest levels of food insecurity (IPC 4 and above) are particularly facing the highest risk of a deterioration in the nutrition and health status. In order to combat the combined impact the aforementioned factors that will be aggravated by the oncoming winter, WFP plans to implement winterization Nutrition assistance to treat the increased cases of moderate acute malnutrition among 34,000 children and PLW in 11 HRP priority provinces with a total commodity requirement of 560 MT. To do this WFP needs about USD 1.5million. As WFP has already received some funding support from CERF and USAID that contributes to about 70% of the winterization needs mentioned above, this current AHF contribution will enable WFP to cover and additional 17% of the winterization needs which will reduce the resource gap accordingly. With this funding, WFP will prioritize 4 provinces experiencing the highest food insecurity but having the lowest coverage of malnutrition treatment services. These include Daikundi, Badakhshan, Ghor, and Badghis. In the above locations, a lot of malnourished children and PLW are often left with no treatment support due to limited resources. The funding from AHF 6th reserve allocation will not only contribute to the winterization resource needs, but also enable WFP to increase the OPD-MAM (TSFP) coverage in theses and selected provinces. WFP’s Targeted Supplementary Feeding Programmes (TSFPs) is an integral component of the Integrated Management of Acute Malnutrition (IMAM). The TSFPs (OPD-MAM) are integrated with UNICEF’s supported Outpatient and Inpatient Therapeutic Feeding Programmes (OPD-SAM, IPD-SAM), whenever and wherever possible, with linkages from the community to health facilities,. WFP’s TSFPs (OPD-MAM) maximize the impact of IMAM by treating children with moderate acute malnutrition (MAM) before they become severely malnourished and malnourished pregnant amp lactating women thereby significantly reducing the burden on SAM treatment and health system in general. TSFP is implemented in partnership with national and international NGO Cooperating Partners who are delivering the Basic Package of Health Service. This proposal specifically focuses on the procurement of specialized nutritious foods (SNFs) for treatment of moderate acute malnourished children and PLW (Pregnant and Lactating Women) in the prioritized provinces. With the US$ 250,000 from AHF 6th reserve allocation WFP will procure approximately 38.8 MT supercereal and 50 MT RUSF. This quantity can cover the treatment requirement of 4,700 children and 1,500 pregnant and lactating women in the selected provinces. Given the foreseen increase in vulnerability during winter and compromised access to several locations, WFP will prioritize prepositioning of MAM treatment commodities in the selected districts within the provinces prioritized under this grant.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency Food Assistance to Food Insecure Population Groups in Badakhshan

description.narrative:
The proposed project aims to provide life-saving assistance to address the immediate food needs of 6,500 households (45,500 beneficiaries) and will be implemented in five districts of Badakhshan province (Arghanj Khwah, Kohistan, Koran-wa-Monjan, Raghestan and Yawan), prioritized by the Food Security and Agriculture Cluster (FSAC). Based on FSAC’s analysis and a rapid needs assessment conducted by the Norwegian Afghanistan Committee (NAC), the majority of the population in these hard-to-reach districts are on the ranking of IPC phase 4 (emergency). Considering that the target population is rated as IPC phase 4, this proposed project will be implemented to improve the food security situation through, the distribution of food commodities, based on the cluster’s food basket.
The chosen modality to deliver this assistance will be in-kind support (direct food commodities) to the most food-insecure households, which will enable target beneficiaries to access essential food items for three months. This project aligns with NAC’s current programs to add emergency food assistance to our “food and work program” for food security to ensure that families and their children have access to food of sufficient quality and quantity to meet daily basic needs. NAC will ensure a gender-sensitive selection process, accessible accountability mechanism and gender-balanced field team will ensure easy access by both genders.
All project beneficiaries will be eligible to receive three months of food assistance through direct food distribution. The value of each transfer will be 26.03 USD per month and will cover 50% of the cost of a monthly food basket for a household of seven (based on agreed FSAC standards).
NAC will contribute in two areas where we are currently implementing our Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (NORAD) funded 3-year program. Using our knowledge, experience and trained personnel, NAC will target the beneficiaries of the AHF project with:
1. Nutrition training: beneficiaries will be encouraged through nutrition training, messages and posters on basic healthy cooking practices, using vegetables and child diet diversification, in addition to staple foods. 2. Health training: beneficiaries will be informed about how to prevent and respond to communicable diseases, reducing the risk for the spread of COVID-19, hepatitis, and other diseases that impacts the lives and wellbeing of community members. 3. Responsible parenting: increased spacing between every childbirth will have direct positive effects on infant and maternal mortality rates, and on children’s physical, social, emotional and cognitive development. Awareness raising sessions on nutrition (food safety) and responsible parenting will be reported to the Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (NORAD).
NAC will ensure coordination and cooperation with other stakeholders in proposed project target areas, to avoid any duplication or overlap.
This proposed project will be implemented using in-kind support (food commodities based on the standard food basket of the FSAC cluster). In relation to this, NAC did a rapid market assessment, while developing the concept note and proposal, and found that the only market with the capacity of supplying the necessary food commodities is Faizabad market – the largest market, at the center of the province with daily connection of food supplies from Taloqan (Takhar) and Kunduz provincial markets and even with Mazar-i-Sharif (Balkh) provincial market and the Kabul market. Therefore, NAC will form a committee for purchasing the required food from the Faizabad market and will then distribute the food commodities based on the food distribution plan for the mentioned five districts.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of protection services for conflict-affected displaced and non displaced populations in Herat, Ghor and Badghis Provinces, western Afghanistan

description.narrative: Through this project, CRDSA provides protection services for 34,700 conflict- affected displaced and non-displaced population (6850 men, 10685 women, 8360 boys and 8805 girls) 60% IDP, 40% HC in Herat, Badghis and Ghor provinces The project contains 2 components including 1- Child protection services for 20900 populations including 4250 men, 3350 women, 7160 boys and 6140 girls in 9 districts of 3 targeted provinces of Herat, Badghis and Ghor 2- GBV services for 13800 populations including 2600 men, 7335 women, 1200 boys and 2665 girls in 8 provincial districts of Herat, Badghis and Ghor provinces The project has been designed according to CRDSA assessment with support and recommendation of government departments (DoRR, DoLSAMD as well as HRP 2020 and AHF 1st Standard Allocation 2020 requirements. Through this project a total of 14000 people (including 2850 men, 4570 women 2985 boys and 3595 girls) in Herat, 12650 people ( including 2250 men, 3970 women, 3435 boys and 2995 girls) in Badghis, and 8050 people ( including 1750 men, 2145 women, 1940 boys and 2215 girls) in Ghor will be benefited from GBV and CP services in 9 districts including Shindand, Pahstoon Zarghoon and Karokh in Herat, Qades, Moqur and Qala e now in Badghis as well as Firoozkoh, Dowlatyar and newly established Morghab district in Ghor province, western Afghanistan. The GBV prevention and response will focus on community dialogues regarding GBV awareness, response and prevention (for 7000 people -4500 male and 3500 female) , 4 outreach/mobile PSS (for 2500 people- 100 male, 2400 female) , health, legal and PSS counseling in 2 Women Friendly Health Spaces one in Herat and one in Badghis (for 4000 people), GBV case management and referral (for 300 people) as well as distribution of dignity kits to 3000 GBV survivors including 2220 kits for women and 780 kits for girls( female). GBV 13800 beneficiaries Including 6100 beneficiaries in Herat ( 1200 men, 3270 women, 400 boys and 1230 girls) , 5100 beneficiaries in Badghis ( including 700 men, 2870 women, 500 boys and 1030 girls) and 2600 beneficiaries in Ghor province (including 700 men, 1192 women, 300 boys and 405 girls) will be benefited from GBV awareness and response activities The child protection sub-component will provides child rights and PSS support sessions, CFSs, PSS and case management and referral services for 20900 persons (4250 men, 3350 women, 7160 boys and 6140 girls). A total of 9000 children and their parents/caregivers will receive child rights and PSS support sessions in their homes and communities. necessary actions will be taken to prevent the COVID 19 disease during the sessions, providing child-friendly spaces to 7500 children to minimize the effects of the emergency on their psycho social well-being and development through establishment of 35 CFSs (150 children age 7-18 years per CFS into three shifts) and 5 child friendly schools as well as provision of PSS counseling for 4000 shock affected children and provision of case management/referral services to 400 children who need specialized services
